(retrieved 20 Feb 2011)</ref> |popplace={{Flagicon|Brazil}} [[Brazil]] ([[Amazonas (Brazilian state)|Amazonas State]]) |rels= |langs=Banawá, a dialect of [[Jamamadí language|Jamamadí]] |related=[[Jamamadi]] }} The '''Banawá''' (also '''Banawa''', '''Banavá''', '''Jafí''', '''Kitiya''', '''Banauá''') are an [[indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] group living along the [[Banawá River]] in the [[Amazonas State, Brazil]]. Their territory is between the [[Juruá River|Juruá]] and [[Purus River]]s.<ref name=pib/> Approximately 158 Banawá people live in one major village and two smaller settlements containing a single extended family each. The Banawá, who call themselves '''Kitiya''', speak a dialect of the [[Jamamadi language|Madi language]]. ==History== Their territory was invaded at the end of the 19th century, during the [[rubber boom]]. In the 1990s, Brazil formally recognized their land rights.<ref name=pib/> ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Banawa people}} [[Category:Indigenous peoples of the Amazon]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Brazil]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Brazil]] [[Category:Arawan languages]] {{Brazil-ethno-group-stub}}
